[01] [g=reading][qu]“Foremost of the Peach Orchard”[/qu]Title awarded to female impersonator and actor Mei Lan-Fang [1894-1962]. [color=blue]13[/color]

[02] [source]NYT Aug 9 1961 “Stage Actor, Dies: Top Chinese Star Was Noted Female Impersonator.”New York Times (9 August 1961): 33. Obituary for Mei Lan-Fang, 67. The piece clarifies that the title “Foremost of the Peach Orchard” indicated that Mei was “without a peer as an actor in China.” The actor emerged from retirement after WWII and became a deputy of the National People’s Congress in 1955; he did not join the Communist Party until 1959. [01] [g=reading][ul]R Southey[/ul] Southey, Robert [1774-1843]. English poet, associated with Romanticism. Moore pastes in a section of a newspaper article on his work that she apparently clipped in 1916 and retained. It is comprised of two of Southey’s poems, “The Locust” and “The Sea Anemone,” with annotations, presumably hers. We reproduce here only her notes and the lines she annotates. [source]NY. Times May 7) 1916

[03] May 7, 1916[/source] Artz, V. T.“Letters from Book Review Readers.” New York Times (7 May 1916): B197. Letter to the editor defending the continued value of Southey’s poetry in 1916, and the view that he is still appreciated by some discriminating readers.
